questions:
You are a ST1 in General Medicine. You are showing the local mayor around the new endoscopy unit when you receive a fast bleep from your ward. You told the ward manager before leaving and asked her not to bleep you for the next two hours.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
A fast bleep represents an emergency situation which you should attend immediately regardless of what you are currently doing. Phoning the ward introduces delay as does bleeping your ST1 colleague. They may also not be available and will not know the patients on your ward as you do.

Asking the F1 doctor to assess as emergency situations will invariably require more senior input than a first-year doctor. Ignoring the bleep is irresponsible and dangerous.

Tell the nurse you don't agree with her decision and explain to the family what has happened

questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on a medical ward. On arriving at the ward you are stopped by the son of one of your patients. They have stayed with him overnight as he is dying from terminal lung cancer. He reports that his dad is getting breakthrough pain. After prescribing a stat dose of diamorphine you hand the chart to the staff nurse who tells you that she is busy with handover and will give it afterwards.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
Whilst this may not be a medical emergency it is certainly urgent. Administration of drugs is primarily the job of a nurse and it is therefore appropriate to speak to the most senior nurse on the ward and explain your concerns. If this still does not work then the doctor themselves should give the drug to ensure that the patient does not endure pain longer than is necessary.

The last three options are poor choices. Confrontation with the nurse will probably make her defensive and is unlikely to achieve your goal. Involving the family in the situation will make them worry about the quality of care they are receiving at a stressful time.

Asking the family to be patient is a poor option when a terminally ill man is in pain. It is not an unreasonable request that he should prompt and effective pain relief. Doing nothing is the worst option as it leaves the family unsure what is happening and delays pain relief being given.

questions:
A 34-year-old man comes for advice regarding a cough. You note from your records he has recently been diagnosed with HIV following a visit to the local genito-urinary clinic. On talking to the patient you become aware that he has a pregnant wife (gestation 16 weeks) who is not aware of his HIV-positive status. Further to this he advised his wife not to have a HIV test at the booking visit as he told her she was not at risk. He states that there is no point telling her now as they are not having sex whilst she is pregnant. Despite discussing the benefits of peripartum treatment for HIV he refuses to tell his wife.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The GMC guidance on confidentiality gives the following advice:
'Disclosure of personal information without consent may be justified in the public interest where failure to do so may expose the patient or others to risk of death or serious harm. Where the patient or others are exposed to a risk so serious that it outweighs the patient's privacy interest, you should seek consent to disclosure where practicable.'

Clearly the best option is for the patient to tell his wife first. This is a good example of a situation where breaking confidentiality may prevent serious harm to both his wife and unborn child. It is therefore justified to break confidentiality in this situation. In order to maintain patient trust it is a good practice to inform the patient before you break confidentiality.

Keeping confidentiality, even for 1 week, puts his wife and unborn child at an unacceptable risk.

Option B is the worst, clearly waiting until the child is born is too late.

options: Use the Mental Health Act to give antibiotics
Check if they have an 'Advanced Care Plan' or Lasting Power of Attonery
Accept her decision to refuse antibiotics and review the situation tomorrow

questions:
You are a junior doctor working on a Care of the Elderly ward. You are called to assess a 90-year-old lady with advanced dementia with has developed a fever and cough. She looks unwell and you suspect that she may have developed a hospital-acquired pneumonia. When you offer her antibiotic treatment, she shouts that she does not want it and wants you to leave her alone. On assessment, it is clear that she lacks the capacity to make this decision. What do you do?

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation (A=Most appropriate; E= Least appropriate)
notes:
The Mental Capacity Act (MCA) provides a statutory framework to empower and protect vulnerable people who are not able to make their own decisions. It is underpinned by five key principles:
  • A presumption of capacity
  • The right for individuals to be supported to make their own decisions
  • Individuals with capacity retain the right to make what might be seen as eccentric or unwise decisions
  • Anything done for or on behalf of people without capacity must be in their best interests
  • Anything done for or on behalf of people without capacity should be the least restrictive of their basic rights and freedoms

To assess if the person has capacity:
  • Does the person have an impairment of the mind or brain, or a disturbance of mental function? - In this case, YES, dementia
  • If so, does that impairment mean that the person is unable to make the decision in question at the time it needs to be made?
  • Can the person understand information relevant to the decision, retain it, use it in the decision-making process, i.e. weigh up pros and cons, and communicate the decision - WE ARE TOLD SHE FAILED THE CAPACITY ASSESSMENT

The best response (option B) is to check whether she has an 'Advanced Care Plan' (decisions made regarding treatment prior to the person losing capacity) or a Lasting Power of Attorney (a person appointed to make decisions on the patient's behalf should they lose capacity).

If the person lacks capacity, as does the lady in the scenario, a clinician can provide treatment if it is deemed in the best interest of the patient. You should, however, in the process of making a best interests decision, try and involve the patient, consider their wishes, consult with others involved in their care e.g. family members. Option E is, therefore, the next most appropriate response as it is the only one which fits within the decision-making process, and thus should occur prior to giving treatment if possible.

The next best response is to give the antibiotics as you have applied the MCA test, which is option D.

It would not be in her best interests to accept her refusal in this scenario as she is lacking in capacity therefore answer C comes next. The worst response would be A, to treat her compulsorily under the MHA. because whether she has capacity or not, you cannot use it to treat a physical health condition.

title: Mental Capacity Act
body:
The Mental Capacity Act of 2005 came into force in 2007. It applies to adults over the age of 16 and sets out who can take decisions if a patient becomes incapacitated (e.g. following a stroke). Mental capacity includes the ability to make decisions affecting daily life, healthcare and financial issues.

The Act contains 5 key principles:
  • A person must be assumed to have capacity unless it is established that he lacks capacity
  • A person is not to be treated as unable to make a decision unless all practicable steps to help him to do so have been taken without success
  • A person is not to be treated as unable to make a decision merely because he makes an unwise decision
  • An act done, or decision made, under this Act for or on behalf of a person who lacks capacity must be done, or made, in his best interests
  • Before the act is done, or the decision is made, regard must be had to whether the purpose for which it is needed can be as effectively achieved in a way that is less restrictive of the person's rights and freedom of action

Assessment of capacity

The Act sets out a clear test for assessing whether a person lacks capacity. It is a 'decision-specific' and 'time-specific' test. An adult can only be considered unable to make a particular decision if:

1. He or she has an 'impairment of, or disturbance in, the functioning of the mind or
brain' whether permanent or temporary AND

2. He or she is unable to undertake any of the following
  • a. understand the information relevant to the decision
  • b. retain that information
  • c. use or weigh that information as part of the process of making the decision
  • d. communicate the decision made by talking, sign language or other means

No individual can be labelled 'incapable' simply as a result of a particular medical condition. Section 2 of the Act makes it clear that a lack of capacity cannot be assumed by a person's age, appearance, or any condition or aspect of a person's behaviour

Best interests

The following should be considered when assessing what is in someone's best interests:
  • 1. Whether the person is likely to regain capacity and can the decision wait.
  • 2. How to encourage and optimise the participation of the person in the decision.
  • 3. The past and present wishes, feelings, beliefs, values of the person and any other relevant factors
  • 4. Views of other relevant people

Lasting Powers of Attorney (LPAs)

The Act allows a person to appoint an attorney to act on their behalf if they should lose capacity in the future, replacing the current Enduring Power of Attorney (EPA). In addition to property and financial affairs the Act also allows people to empower an attorney make health and welfare decisions. The attorney only has the authority to make decisions about life-sustaining treatment if the LPA specifies that. Before it can be used an LPA must be registered with the Office of the Public Guardian

Advance decisions

Advance decisions can be drawn up by anybody with capacity to specify treatments they would not want if they lost capacity. They may be made verbally unless they specify refusing life-sustaining treatment (e.g. Ventilation) in which case they need to be written, signed and witnessed to be valid. Advance decisions cannot demand treatment

questions:
You are a ST1 doctor on a medical ward. The F1 doctor is coming to the end of his rotation and has asked you to complete an online assessment of his performance. During the rotation you've felt that the F1 has struggled with both the organisational and knowledge aspects of his role. Despite this you like the doctor personally and he is always polite and courteous to the staff on the ward.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This is reasonably straightforward. Workplace based assessments and now an integral part of both the Foundation Programme and Specialist Training. They rely on honest feedback from colleagues about a doctors performance to allow an accurate assessment of their progress to be made.

The best answer is to complete the feedback report honestly and accurately. It is even better if you can spend time with them to give your perspective on their strengths and weaknesses.

The next dilemma is whether to give him 4 weeks to improve or just refuse. Giving him 4 weeks is a slightly better response as it may allow an accurate assessment to be completed, albeit delayed. Refusing to do a report because you may have negative things to say simply skews the results.

Giving a falsely positive report, whilst well intentioned, risks the doctor not being made aware of his shortcomings.

questions:
You are a junior doctor on-call in colorectal surgery. You have just finished a ward round and are getting bleeped to do a number of different tasks. Which 3 should take priority and which 5 can wait until later?

Select the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
This question tests how the candidate prioritises tasks. The treatment of acutely ill patients is the most important responsibility of the junior doctor on-call. A patient with a NEWS score of 5 could rapidly deteriorate and so you must assess them as soon as possible. Similarly, you have a patient who became acutely unwell overnight and so whatever needs to be done for them, in this case booking an x-ray, should also be done as soon as possible. Of the remaining options, the most patient with the most acute problem is the one requiring a cannula for abdominal sepsis. A patient on IV antibiotics is by default acutely unwell therefore you should also do this task quickly.

The GP referral with loose stool could potentially be a serious problem therefore finding out as much information as possible when you are referred a patient can help you prioritise it into your jobs list. Discharge letters, routine bloods, and referrals are all important jobs but are not as imminently important as the others.

title: General Medical Council: duties of a doctor
body:
Make the care of your patient your first concern

Protect and promote the health of patients and the public
  • Provide a good standard of practice and care
  • Keep your professional knowledge and skills up to date
  • Recognise and work within the limits of your competence
  • Work with colleagues in the ways that best serve patients' interests

Treat patients as individuals and respect their dignity
  • Treat patients politely and considerately
  • Respect patients' right to confidentiality

Work in partnership with patients
  • Listen to patients and respond to their concerns and preferences
  • Give patients the information they want or need in a way they can understand
  • Respect patients' right to reach decisions with you about their treatment and care
  • Support patients in caring for themselves to improve and maintain their health

Be honest and open and act with integrity
  • Act without delay if you have good reason to believe that you or a colleague may be putting patients at risk
  • Never discriminate unfairly against patients or colleagues
  • Never abuse your patients' trust in you or the public's trust in the profession.
concept: As a doctor on call, you must be able to prioritise tasks and provide prompt assessment and treatment for those patients who are acutely unwell

questions:
During a radiology rotation, you are assigned a weekly ultrasound list with a senior registrar. You have been shadowing the registrar and watching him scan patients for several weeks. You have not practiced scanning any patients and find you are not learning anything from these sessions.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
It is important to be proactive and take responsibility for your own learning and personal development. Additionally, you should recognise that all doctors, particularly senior registrars, and consultants have a responsibility to supervise and teach as part of their job.

In this situation, it would be appropriate to speak to the registrar about your expectations and ask if you can scan patients. The registrar may not be familiar with what your learning/ curriculum needs are. They may not even be aware that you are supposed to be learning how to carry out ultrasounds during these sessions instead of just shadowing.
Seeking advice from your clinical supervisor would also be appropriate if you were unsure how to approach the registrar or felt uncomfortable doing so. Your clinical supervisor is your first port of call for any queries or problems that arise during your clinical rotation.

It would not be appropriate to stop attending these sessions as this is a timetabled session you are expected to not only attend but engage with and develop your range of clinical skills.

It would not be appropriate to complete a DATIX at this stage as you have not yet tried to address the issue with the registrar involved or your clinical supervisor.

Attending a different ultrasound list is not appropriate unless your clinical supervisor decides this would be necessary if the situation did not improve.

You could discuss with your educational supervisor but your clinical supervisor is more likely to be able to help with problems during a specific clinical rotation. Your educational supervisor is likely not to be based within the clinical environment you are working in.

It would be inappropriate to inform the clinical director of the department or inform the registrar's supervisor as you should try to address the issue with the registrar himself first and then see advice from your clinical or educational supervisor on how to proceed.

Do nothing is clearly inappropriate in this scenario.

title: GMC Guidance: Teaching, training and assessing
body:
All medical professionals
  • Clinical and professional skills are largely developed through on-the-job training during placements.
  • All doctors should model professionalism when interacting with patients, colleagues, and learners.
  • If you’re involved in workplace teaching, you must demonstrate effective teaching practices, including respect for diversity and reasonable adjustments for disabilities, without compromising safety or standards.

Medical professionals with teaching leadership roles
  • Ensure teaching is delivered by suitably skilled professionals.
  • Maintain adequate staffing across disciplines to support education and supervision.
  • Use systems to identify and document the learning needs of trainees and locums.
  • Create inclusive learning environments and make reasonable adjustments under the Equality Act 2010.
  • Support ongoing development for trainers and ensure regular feedback and appraisal systems are in place.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
This is a formal inquiry into the death of a patient and, as such, you are legally obligated to cooperate. You are also obligated to take reasonable steps to ensure your statement is factually accurate, including reviewing the patient's notes. See the link below for further details.

https://resolution.nhs.uk/resources/giving-evidence-at-inquest-a-well-prepared-witness/

A: You should not unduly delay cooperating, and other options here provide better methods for ensuring your statement is accurate
B: This is a sensible and easy step to ensure the information you provide is accurate as it may jog your memory of the events surrounding that patient
C: Asking another healthcare worker's recollection will influence your account of the events in a way that could be construed as falsification, as there experience is not the same as yours
D: You are legally obligated to participate in formal inquiries
E: Rushing the writing of the statement may lead to inaccuracy and does not show due diligence
F: Your medical defence organisation is likely able to educate you on the legalities of the situation, which you are unfamiliar with, and provide you with advice
G: Similar to the account of the nurse, this will bias your perception of events
H: In the absence of other appropriate options, this should be included. Seeking advice from a senior in this way is sensible, as they will have experience with this kind of proceeding

title: Inquest
body:
An inquest is a public enquiry into a death, held at Coroner's Court. You may be required to attend an inquest at some point during your career to give evidence about your involvement in the care of a patient who died. It is a legal proceeding but not a criminal one - it cannot apportion blame or responsibility to a person or body; its purpose is to determine who, where, when and how. However, like a criminal proceeding, you may be questioned by a lawyer representing the patient, there may be a jury, and the press may be present.

Source: http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/Inquest/Pages/Introduction.aspx

options: Order some alcohol for the Christmas party - if he refuses contact the police
Advise him on medical issues but inform him that you have no choice but to phone the police as soon as he leaves the room
Advise him to refrain from importing alcohol and arrange a follow-up appointment
Advise him on medical issues but take no further action
Phone Crimestoppers anonymously to maintain the doctor-patient relationship
questions:
During a consultation the patient mentions that his main source of income is illegally importing alcohol from France to the UK.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This question is about judgement and the boundaries of the doctor's role.

Doctors are only required to break confidentiality and inform the police to prevent serious crime; illegally importing alcohol would not constitute a serious crime. Your role should therefore be confined to providing advice on medical issues. Advising him to refrain from importing alcohol may seem reasonable but the patient may interpret this as judgemental and it hence may interfere with the doctor-patient relationship.

Contacting the police is not appropriate as it breaks confidentiality without just cause. Phoning Crimestoppers anonymously is even worse.

It is difficult to envisage a worse response than to blackmail him in order to obtain alcohol for the Christmas party!
